{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3531839,"name":"Jason Evans","username":"j.e","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/j.e/{size}/175324_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T19:58:15.628Z","cooked":"

The LaserCAN RegionOfInterest docs do not specify the coordinate system for (x,y), nor do they specify the translation for (w,h). Our assumption when reading through the Java example code, as well as when looking at the GrappleHook page, was that the SPAD array is in the first quadrant, i.e. in the spaces between integer points [(0,0)…(16,16)], and that (w,h) is centered on (x,y). However, we noticed while reading about elevator implementations that BroncBotz 3481 treats the SPAD array as centered on the origin, i.e. [(-8,-8)…(8,8)], which appears to be consistent with the VL53L1X datasheet, section 3.8.

I don’t see any evidence of origin translation in the LaserCAN firmware code. Are the Java/C++ example programs specifying the center of the ROI incorrectly? Guidance (and explicit documentation) would be much appreciated.

[Edit] I’ve just found the API user manual for the sensor, and section 2.5.6 has me even more confused. That API description suggests that the SPAD array is in the first quadrant, and that the ROI should be specified as top-left, bottom-right points, i.e. (0, 15), (15, 0) to use the entire sensor. But the data structure contains four 8-bit fields, whereas the LaserCAN firmware uses 8-bit fields for (x,y), and 16-bit fields for (w,h). Elsewhere I saw mention of 4.4 format for low-level (x,y) coordinates. So, I’m really confused, not sure what layers of abstraction are actually connected together in the LaserCAN.

Hi, the ROI is the same as what’s configured in GrappleHook which is the intended way to select the ROI you need, translating into robot code if you need.

image471×668 31.1 KB

I’ll update the docs with the convention - it’s x,y = centre point, w,h = width and height respectively. The user manual from the sensor is low level implementation detail - the conversion between the conventions is done on the LaserCAN itself
